trigger: Increased <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in airway cells of glucocorticoid-insensitive asthma .
Glucocorticoid ( GC ) - insensitive asthma is a challenging clinical problem that can be associated with life-threatening disease progression .
The molecular basis of GC insensitivity is unknown .

Alternative splicing of the <extra_id_0> GC receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> GCR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) pre - mRNA generates a second GCR , termed <extra_id_0> GCRbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which does not bind GC but antagonizes the transactivating activity of the classic <extra_id_0> GCR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Thus increased expression of <extra_id_0> GCRbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> could account for glucocorticoid insensitivity .

Bronchoalveolar lavage ( BAL ) cells and peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) were examined for <extra_id_0> GCRbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> immunoreactivity using a <extra_id_0> GCRbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - specific antibody by immunohistochemical staining .
Cell localization of <extra_id_0> GCRbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression was performed using a double immunostaining technique .

Patients with GC-insensitive asthma expressed a significantly higher number of <extra_id_0> GCRbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - immunoreactive cells in their BAL and peripheral blood than GC - sensitive asthmatics or normal control subjects .

Furthermore , <extra_id_0> GCRbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in GC-insensitive asthma was particularly high in airway T cells , which are thought to play a major role in the pathogenesis of asthma .
We also examined the expression of <extra_id_0> GCRbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in specimens from the airways of patients with chronic bronchitis .
In chronic bronchitis , few cells were <extra_id_0> GCRbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - positive and their numbers did not differ significantly from normal control subjects .
We conclude that GC-insensitive asthma is associated with increased expression of <extra_id_0> GCRbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in airway T cells .
